content.description:
This climb is about 10' right of "#22"; it is the rightmost line on the South Side of the Big Enchilada that looks worth considering. Informally called "Three Sisters" because of 3 distinct routes that can be done from the anchors. You can also do at least 3 different routes to get to the ledge, the left one being the best for pro.  

  For the left route, ~5.8+, climb up a blocky dihedral to a ledge.  Climb the headwall above, following the crack in its center that begins as hands, passes over a block, then turns to a finger crack.  Finish on easy slab to an anchor on the blocks at the top. Good gear lead. 

  The middle route follows the left side of the face to the right, using the nose/arÃªte, and has a short 5.10- crux. Best to top rope.  

  The right route follows the next crack to the right, off the rope line, goes at ~5.8, and makes a nice easier lead. Takes gear up to #4 Camalot.
content.protection: Standard rack up to 3 inches.   2-bolt anchor, reachable from the top. Use long slings to extend.
content.location:
Route #23 in Chen/Wehner, as shown on               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #25 (5.9+) and Jackson #8 (5.9+).

content.description: Climb the dihedral right of Route 8 (around the corner) and then up easier cracks to the top.
content.protection: Pro to 3".
content.location:
Route #9 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #11 (5.10d) and Jackson #21 (5.11a/b).

content.description: Climb the dihedral to the roof with a large jammed block. Pass the roof on the left and continue up the vague buttress staying right of route 8.
content.protection: After the initial bouldering move into the wavy dihedral at the base of the route you can place a good finger-sized cam in the jammed block assuming you are 5' 9" or above in height. Part way through the moves over the overhang I found a good medium sized nut that protected the final moves through the hang. The buttress above has some widely spaced gear but you may have to search for it. Good top rope anchors can be placed at the cliff top.
content.location: Start in a wavy dihedral beneath a large roof that is marked by a square-cut undercling block. A few feet right of the start of route 8.

content.description: Look for the big roof near the left end of the Big Enchilada's South Side; choose which bouldery start (crux) to take to let you reach the roof's righthand side.  Move past the big roof in a wide crack with awkward chimneying.  Loose crack climbing leads to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3".
content.location:
Route #8 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Jackson #23 (5.10b) and Beverly's #10 (5.10b), though the start shown by Beverly is a little bit right of those shown in the other guides.

content.description:
The left side the large roof at the left end of the Big Enchilada (south) is split by a fist/offwidth crack. A distinctive pine grows on a ledge above the roof. Two cracks, about three feet apart lead up from the ground to this roof. Climb either the left or right crack, or use both until reaching the ceiling. A sharp flake, apparently solid, is used to start the moves through the roof. Easier climbing to the top.

 Note that Wa3lt's               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.       shows a right finish, while Beverly's and Jackson's topos show a left finish.
content.protection: If you want to practice this climb on top rope then you should throw your ropes from the top anchor to the (skiers) left of the pine tree, otherwise you'll be top-roping route 6. This climb is a well-protected PG lead.
content.location:
Route #7 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      .  Look for the small tree halfway up. 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #9 (5.10c) and Jackson #24 (5.10?).

content.description: A crack system with mostly solid rock. Attain the right side of a prominent ledge via either an off-width crack that splits two pillars, followed by a hand crack, or a partly-vegetated set of blocks and cracks to the left (shown at lower right of route #1.5 photo). The crux and the best climbing is up a finger crack in the middle of the cliff. Above that you have a choice of cracks to the top.
content.protection:
Pro to 3". 

  TR can be set up with one static line to a juniper + gear.
content.location:
Route #5 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #7 (5.10b/c) but is not in Jackson.

content.description: Climb to a small tree growing in the cliff, then to the top. A very loose (avoid) climb.
content.protection: TR
content.location:
Route #6 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #8 (5.10b) and Jackson #25 (5.10?).

content.description:
Fun climb up a nice line, with some excellent fist jams. The large crack system at the left end of the crag. Begin by climbing to a ledge, then a hand/fist crack to the top. 

  Also, from the ledge you can climb up the route 3 crack for ~10 ft then angle up a ramp to the right to meet the upper part of route 5, bypassing both cruxes. Nice ~5.8 lead.
content.protection:
Gear to 3". 

  TR can be set up with 2 static lines, one to a juniper and one around a boulder
content.location:
Route #3 in Chen/Wehner, but is not in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #5 (5.9) but is not in Jackson.

content.description:
If you're going to climb a 5.11 at the Big Enchilada, this is a good choice. 

  Up a broken dihedral, pull a small roof, and layback (1st crux) up to another overhung crux passing over a bulge below the prow.
content.protection: TR, or lead this with a standard rack up to 2", with 2 ea. of smaller cams and TCUs helpful.   2-bolt anchor, reachable from the top.
content.location:
Route #22 in Chen/Wehner, as shown on               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #24 (5.11a) and Jackson #9 (5.11a).

content.description: Up and leftwards on blocky cracks to a big ledge. From the right end of the ledge, straight up the finger crack (crux).
content.protection: TR, or lead it with a standard rack up to 3"
content.location:
Route #21 in Chen/Wehner, as shown on               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #23 (5.10d) and Jackson #10 (5.10d).

content.description:
Up the loose dihedral and out the right side of a roof via offwidth. 

  South Side beta photo and Beverly both show this route going right and joining Headjam 1/2-2/3 of the way up, but if you stay left through the off-width crux (maybe 5.9+ or 5.10-, good knee jam possible if you have smallish legs), you can parallel Headjam to near the top as shown by Jackson.
content.protection: TR, or lead it with a rack that includes 1 or more #4 camalots and optional larger cams.   2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
Route #19 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #21 (5.9) and Jackson #12 (5.9).

content.description: Up a loose dihedral to a nice handcrack, traverse left to a rest on a good ledge, lieback and jam as you move up, and then back right to a corner. Finish straight up a beautiful hand crack.
content.protection: Pro to 2.5 inches.   2-bolt anchor, reachable from the top.
content.location:
Route #18 as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      .  Note, however, that this is listed as Route #17 in the Chen/Wehner online guide. 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #20 (5.9) and Jackson #14 (5.9+).

content.description: Up a bouldery start (crux) with tricky protection to a good ledge.  The clean right-facing dihedral above is excellent and well-protected.  The first obstacle is turning a 2' roof with jugs to a lieback, followed by sustained stemming in the corner.  A brief and easier offwidth section concludes the climb.
content.protection: Standard rack to 2.5 inches.   2-bolt anchor, reachable from the top.
content.location:
Route #17 as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      .  Note, however, that this is listed as Route #16 in the Chen/Wehner online guide. 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #19 (5.10c) and Jackson #15 (5.10a).

content.description: Climb either of 2 steep starts to a loose ledge, then straight up the face, staying right to avoid the crack. Contrived.
content.protection: TR
content.location:
Route #16 as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      .  This is NOT THE SAME as Route #16 in the Chen/Wehner online guide. 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #18 (5.12a), but is not in Jackson.

content.description:
Climb straight up the broken-ish crack system, which turns into a right-facing corner and turns a roof up high, and ends just right of the tree. 

  Midway up the cliff, it's recommended (and slightly easier) to step right to a big flake above a clean face.  Pull through 2 bulges and top out right of the tree.
content.protection: Pro to 3"
content.location:
Route #15 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.       (which shows the left variation for the upper portion of the climb). 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #17 (5.9+) and Jackson #16 (5.9+). Beverly's topo shows the righthand variation of this climb.

content.description: Easy terrain to a small roof (crux) then easier above.
content.protection: TR, probably.
content.location:
Route #13 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #15 (5.11c/d) and Jackson #17 (5.11b).

content.description: Difficult face moves to easier cracks (are you sensing a theme here yet?)
content.protection: TR, probably.
content.location:
Route #12 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #14 (5.11c) and Jackson #18 (5.11c/d). Jackson's finish is a little different.

content.description: Start about 8' right of the petroglyphs, in a small open dihedral.  Climb a seam in the dihedral, to some difficult face moves passing 2 roofs.  Follow easier crack terrain above, bearing a little to the right.
content.protection: Probably best to TR; can be led with nuts and cams up to 3", with small wired nuts and a #2 camalot protecting the crux moves.
content.location:
Route #11 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #13 (5.11b/c) and Jackson #19 (5.11c). 

  This is the next obvious start about 8' right of the rock art.

content.description: Climb an obvious layback starting just left of the triangular petroglyph, and then up through blocky roofs (bouldery crux).  Angle up and right, finishing up on easier blocky cracks.
content.protection: Pro to 3"
content.location:
Route #10 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #12 (5.10d/5.11a) and Jackson #20 (5.11b/c).

content.description: Blocky climbing at the base leads to a short, clean, arching offwidth, into which it is difficult to gain entry.  Past the offwidth, to the right, a chimney leads to the top.   This route is described and pictured by Beverly (2006:200-201) as Route #2. It is also apparently route #1 in the Chen/Wehner on-line guide. Jackson (2006) doesn't list any routes this far left on the crag (although he has a photo covering this area on page 186).
content.protection: At least one #6 Friend or C4 will be needed, or the equivalent.  Multiples of biggies would probably be desirable so you don't have to walk up your first big placement.   Build a gear anchor on top.  Beverly says to TR it, but it might be difficult to toprope because it traverses so much.
content.location: Near the far left (western) end of the south face of the Big E. The route ascends the left wall of a large right-facing corner.  Go left of the pinon tree that marks the bottom of the Dihedral climb. Even though we're on the south face of the Big E, this climb gets early PM shade thanks to the big left wall.

content.description: Easy moves on jugs to a crux reach in the right-facing dihedral. High quality, but loose.
content.protection: TR, or lead it with TCUs protecting the crux.
content.location:
Route #14 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #16 (5.11b), but is not in Jackson.

content.description: Up a narrow face. Don't use the cracks on either side. Contrived, but fun.
content.protection: TR
content.location:
Route #4 in Chen/Wehner, as shown in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #6 (5.12a) but is not in Jackson.

content.description: Begin by stemming your way up an ever-steepening obvious wide slot (this is where the 4" piece may come in handy, although smaller gear options exist deeper in the fissure). Pull through the awkward bulge, gain the ledge, and continue up the broken dihedral (same finish as for Route 19).
content.protection: Standard rack up to 3" (4" optional at bottom) to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
Route #20 in Chen/Wehner, as shown on               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #22 (5.9) and Jackson #11 (5.9).

content.description: Climb up blocky dihedral to ledge, as in the Three Sisters. From ledge, trend left up prominent crack system, joining upper part of Route 22. Can be toproped, with some swing potential during opening moves (possible crux of route).
content.protection: Standard rack, up to #4 or 4.5 Camalot.   2-bolt anchor, reachable from top.
content.location: Starts at bottom of Three Sisters, Route #23 in Chen/Wehner, as shown on the South Side beta photo, and heads up to Route 22 anchors.

content.description: An interesting, easy, fun dihedral with good protection.  Steep at the top, with some solid 5.6 exit moves (in the same vein as Car Camping with the Kids).  Unfortunately the interesting dihedral part of the climb is only in the top section; the bottom one-third is mainly a blocky ledgy system with some loose-ish boulders.  The climb would warrant two stars or more if it weren't for the bottom part.  In general, it maybe best to situate the belayer slightly off to the right of the base of the route, out of the way of any possible rockfall from the ledges.   This route is described and pictured by Beverly (2006:200-201) as Route #3.  It appears to lie between routes #1 and #2 in the Chen/Wehner on-line guide.  Jackson (2006) doesn't list any routes this far left on the crag (although he has a photo covering this area on page 186).
content.protection: Single set of nuts and cams up to a BD #3.  Maybe doubles of hands to small fists would be reassuring.     A gear anchor can be built at the top, or sling the nearby junipers (only one tree is readily close by, though).
content.location: Near the far left (western) end of the south face of the Big E.  The route ascends a prominent right-facing dihedral that ascends above a broken ledgy area.  A landmark is the christmas-tree-shaped pinon tree growing about 15 feet above the ground, on the ledgy area, just to the left of the base of the dihedral.  Even though we're on the south face of the Big E, this climb gets early afternoon shade thanks to the big left wall.   Two large cholla are growing just left of the base of the route, and a fat claret cup is growing on the upper ledge just to the right of the route.  So, throwing down a toprope could be problematic.  If you need to drop the line from above, maybe move about 10 yards to the east, throw down a line to avoid a cactus collision, and then walk the top of your rope back to your anchor.

content.description: This route provides chimney practice.  There are also good face holds inside the chimney, or you can ignore them and go full-on chimneying.  Unfortunately, it's really short.   This route is described and pictured by Beverly (2006:200-201) as Route #1. It lies left of route #1 in the Chen/Wehner on-line guide. Jackson (2006) doesn't list any routes this far left on the crag (although he has a photo covering this area on page 186).
content.protection: Single trad rack of nuts and cams to maybe 3" will get you up.  No need for big stuff, there's plenty of placements on the inner faces of the chimney itself.  A gear anchor can be built at the top.
content.location: This is the farthest left (west) route described on the south wall of the Big E.  It occupies the left side of a big east-facing corner, so it appears to get early AM sun and early PM shade.   Approach the base of chimney two ways:  From the right, go up the 4th class blocks, or from the left, start up a blocky 5.8-ish crack system to make the actual climbing last longer.

content.description: Scramble up bushy boulders for 15 feet, then climb a steep 45 foot face without using the aretes or cracks (contrived).
content.protection: TR
content.location:
Route #2 in Chen/Wehner, but is not covered in               

South side of the Big Enchilada. Sorry for the poor quality, this is a photo of a photo.      . 

  This climb is also listed as Beverly #4 (5.12a) but is not in Jackson.

content.description: The south side of The Big Enchilada hosts about 25 crack climbs of reasonable to good quality. Most of these will require trad anchors. The cliff actually faces a bit southwest, and hence sees sun from late morning through the end of the day. The leftmost routes on this wall occupy a big eastish-facing corner, though, so receive earlier sun and shade.
